title: Understanding Diprotic Acids
text: A diprotic acid can donate two protons (H⁺ ions) in solution. The dissociation occurs in two steps, each with its own equilibrium constant, Ka1 and Ka2.

title: Dominant Dissociation
text: When Ka1 is significantly larger than Ka2, the first dissociation step is the primary contributor to the concentration of H⁺ ions in the solution.

title: Calculating H⁺ Concentration
text: For the first dissociation step, H2A dissociates into H⁺ and HA⁻. The equilibrium expression is Ka1 ext{=}([H**+][HA**-])/([H_2A]).

title: Setting Up the Equation
text: Assume [H⁺] $$ext{=}[HA⁻]$$ and [H2A] ext{=}[H2A]_0-[H⁺]. Substitute these into the equilibrium expression for Ka1.

title: Simplifying the Equation
text: Since Ka1 is large, assume $$x$$ is small compared to $$0.10$$. Simplify the equation to find $$x$$.

title: Solving for $$x$$
text: Solve the simplified equation for $$x$$, which represents [H⁺].

title: Calculating pH
text: The pH is calculated using the formula pH ext{=}-log([H⁺]).

title: Final Calculation
text: Substitute the value of [H⁺] into the pH formula to find the pH of the solution.
